Y.M.C.A. HOLDS ANNUAL ELECTION
Hall Chosen President— New Plan of
Election Effective—Announcement
Made that Sunday Will Not
Speak at Hopkins.

The annual election of officers of
the Young Men's Christian Association took place last Friday at
noon, with the following results:
President, F. P. Hall, 17; VicePresident, A. K. Chalmers, '18;
Recording Secretary, R. F. Hoffman, .18 ; Corresponding Secretary, H. E. Kirk, Jr., 19; Treasurer, W. L. Taylor, 18.
These men will be called together some time in the near future
by the present assistant general
secretary, and will then appoint
their committee chairmen for next
year. After this, the new officers
will immediately enter upon the
fulfillment of their respective duties.
Not only have most of these officers had a large amount of experience in Young Men's Christian
Association work, but all of them
are also prominent in other Hopkins activities. Included in their
number are the present captains of
both the track and the tennis team,
and the manager of the baseball
team.
The plan of electing the officers
at a general mass-meeting of the
students will probably be used altogether in the future. It is felt
that, by this means, the entire University is made to take more active
interest in the affairs of the Association..
That the coming year will be an
unusually successful one for the
Young Men's Christian Association, is the opinion of the present
officers. They point out that, next
fall, the University will be drawn
closer together because of its location at Homewood, and, in this
manner, the Association will be
able to accomplish its work with
increased effectiveness.
The Association has announced
this week, although with much regret, that it will not be possible
for Mr. Sunday to speak at the
University. There seems to be no
time which would be suitable to the
evangelist which would not conflict
with the regular Hopkins curriculum.

The work on the debate on
versal military training with the
universities of North Carolina and
Virginia is now progressing rapidly. The men upholding the opposite sides of the question had a
meeting last week at which the subject in all its phases was thoroughly discussed. The results of the
consultation proved so beneficial
that is has been decided to hold
many such meetings in the future.
With the time for the debate
rapidly drawing near, both teams
are satisfied with the material that
has been gathered and feel that a
double victory is well within the
realm of possibility.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 3, 1916.
The Turnbull Lectures.

The crowning event of the lecture season of the University is now
in the course of fruition. Since
their foundation, the Turnbull lectures have been regarded in academic circles as one of the most
important series delivered throughout the country, and the men who
have been selected under this
foundation in the past have been
men who have stood to the fore in
their respective fields, and who
have enjoyed reputations for
scholarship not only in this country,
but also throughout all Europe.
The selection made by the committee this year, measured by these
standards, is particularly happy.
Dr. More is a man who, both
in scholastic and in journalistic endeavor, has achieved heights which
grant to him, without question, the
right to be considered one of the
foremost literary men of the day.
His subject also is one which is of
peculiar interest to Hopkins men,
including as it does the consideration of Sidney Lanier, the poet
whom Hopkins will always proudly
regard as its own. Yet, in itself,
the subject of "The Poets of
America" should be one to awaken
interest in every man who has
dipped, even if only slightly, into
the pages of our national literature.
The enormous attendance which
each of the lectures so far given
has drawn is ample proof of the
keen interest and delight which the
announcement of both lecturer and
subject has evoked throughout the

NINE DOES WELL IN FIRST GAME
Playing for First Time in Open, Allow
Baltimore Orioles to Score Only
9 Runs—Creditable Showing
Bodes Well for Hopkins.

The Hopkins baseball team appeared before the public for the
first time this season when they met
the Baltimore Orioles at Oriole
Park last Saturday afternoon, and
held them to the creditable score of
9 too.
The Hopkins nine has had practically no outdoor work this year,
and previous to the game, had batted against only straight balls. The
practice game with the Orioles was
scheduled only a week ago, and,
all things considered, the fact that
the local nine held the professionals
to a score which would not have
disgraced a member of the International League, despite the fact
that the Orioles have been in training grounds over a month, bodes
well for the outlook of the team.
The score of last Saturday's
game:

The large attendance which
greeted the local Young Men's
Christian Association's first election to be held before a student
mass-meeting is significant. It
shows that the efforts of the Association to draw the University
closer together and to render the
service of the kind which only an
organization of its kind can render
is appreciated by the student body
—that Hopkins is beginning to realize that the Young Men's Christian
Association is as much of a student activity as is any branch of
sport, and that it deserves the
hearty interest and support of all
Hopkins men.

made manifest by the results of the
elections themselves. The men who

'VARSITY WINS FIRST GAME
(Continued from page 1)

to return to form is a week of hard
practice.
Of the men who made their first
appearance as 'Varsity players,
Schmidt and Swartz deserve especial mention. The former played a splendid game at cover-point
during the time he was in the game,
and while at times a bit uncertain
in his "going through," showed•
much natural athletic ability.
Swartz was at first very wild in his
attempts at goal, when substituted
in the second half, but toward the
end of the contest settled down and
showed work of considerable promise. Meyer and Wilson also played
well, but not in a noticeable manner. A word should, however, be
said of the work of Arthur Knipp
at in-home. Knipp last played on
the 'Varsity team in 1906, but his
work gave no evidence of the lapse
of years; "once a lacrosse player,
always a lacrosse player."
For the Alumni, La Motte, Mealy.
and Lowndes were the bright
lights: The first two did all their
team's scoring while advisor "Bob"
was a wonder in the mid-field. His
condition was probably the best of
the Alumni, since he had practiced
steadily with the 'Varsity for over
a week. In addition to them the
whole Alumni defense should be
mentioned, especially the work of
Chalmers at goal. Walter Blank
was not on the job for the graduates
for the first time in many years,
and in his stead Chalmers, who is
a 'Varsity sub, was used. Some of
his stops were of a most spectacular nature and he gives promise of
being a most worthy substitute for
Stuart.
As has been the custom, for
years, no admission was charged
for the contest, and an audience of
over 800 friends of the teams were
present in response to the invitations which had been sent out. The
student body, however, was not at
all well represented and had there
been need of cheering it would have
been impossible. The coaches and
the team as a whole look for, and
confidently expect, better support
on next Saturday when Cornell is
to meet in the first intercollegiate
contest.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 3, 1916.

DESCRIBES PROBLEM OF GERMANS DESCRIBE PLATTSBURG CAMPS
Professor Bonn Gives Series of Lectures
on Germany's Present Economic Situation—Says She Was Reluctant to Enter the War.

Messrs. Hoffman and Stuart Tell Why
Hopkins Men Should Attend, Give De- 1
tails of Camps and Show How Expense Can Be Met by All.

Much interest was taken, both
by members of the University and
by outsiders, in the series of lectures delivered in McCoy Hall last
week by Prof. Moritz j. Bonn, of
the University, of Munich, on "Germany's Economic Problem."
In the first of these lectures,
Professor Bonn explained that, in
order that the peculiar genius of
the German people.. might be developed, it was necessary for them to
remain under the German •flag, and
for them to 'speak the. German language.
In his second lecture, he traced
the development of the Germans
from an agricultural to an industrial people. He explained that this
change was brought about so that
work might be found for the ever
increasing; population of. Germany.
He also told how Germany had
adapted itself to these new conditions.
In the final lecture, Dr. Bonn
told of. Germany's international
trade relations. "Germany," he
said, "is in the. very peculiar position of being the only great power
today that has novcolorties of importance." If • England, a'ftth-.. this
war, were .to successfully follow
the example of France, 'Russia and
Japan, he went on, the condition
of Germany's foreign trade would
be very serious, for these countries
charge prohibitive duties on all
goods sent to their colonies from
other nations. Germany has never
wanted to have great colonial possessions like England and France,
he explained, because of her geographical situation.

kt a meeting held at i o'clock
on Monday in McCoy Hall, the
military training camps at Plattsburg, N. Y., were described and
their advantages were discussed by
Messrs. R. • Curzon Hoffman, Jr.,
and Redmond Stuart.
Dean Brush acted as chairman of
the meeting and after a brief speech
introduced' the first speaker, Mr.
Hoffman. Mr. Hoffman" talked on
the history of military camps for
students. He said that they have
been in existence for several years
and have always been well attended,
the number of campers ranging
from 400 to 1,200.
Mr. Stuart, who was the next
speaker, told- of the purpose of the
camps and of the expense involved.
The object of the, camps, he said,
is'to train men' between .tlie:ages. of
18 and 45 in the science of military
drill and maneuvers, and to give
each attendant,as much of the, fundamental education of an .o'ffi'cer
can be imparted in the given.time.
A certain definite routine is Prescribed for all, Mr. Stuart went on,
including infantry training and rifle
practice,. The.. • attendant .,!a,t the
camp are divided into war-strength
companies . of infantry,-' each • of
which is commanded by an officer
of the regular army, whose duties
cover not only those of instruction,
but also those of supervision over
the health and general welfare of
their commands. No examination
is required, but the regular officers
on duty at the camp will make such
reports as to individual qualifications as they may deem proper, to
be filed will; the War Department.
The student camp at Plattsburg,
Which Hopkins men are especially
urged to attend, lasts from July 5.
to•..-kug-ust 8. The expenses at the
camp itself are $22.50, but the total
expenses are nearly $50. The plan
advanced by Mr. Stuart to allow
all to meet this expense is for the
Hopkins students interested in the
camp to form a club and elect a
secretary. Then, if a member could
not. afford to go to the camp this
summer, he could give his name to
the secretary who, in turn, would
notify Mr. Gustavus Ober, secretary of the Maryland National Defense League. Mr. Ober, Mr.
Stuart said, could in all probability
furnish the desired funds. Although no definite organization 'of,
this club has been made, it is probable that such organization will
soon take place.
All who are interested in the
camp can obtain any desired information from Dean Brush or Dr.
Abercrombie.

BILL TO CUT HOPKINS GRANT
INTRODUCED IN LEGISLATURE

A bill has been finally introduced
in the House of Representatives of
the Maryland Legislature by which
the appropriation of the State to
Johns Hopkins University is made
only $50,000, a decrease of $25,000
from the grant of last year.
The bill was introduced on
March 31 by Mr. Bryant, chairman
of the Ways and Means Committee.
Together with the grant to this
University, it carries appropriations to charitable and other institutions supported, wholly or in
part, by the State.
Hope for the full grant of former years to the University has
been by no means abandoned, despite the introduction of the bill.
There is a determined group of
men in the Legislature who are
fighting to the last ditch against the
cut, and there still seems to be an
excellent probability of their efforts
being successful. It is possible that
the additional grant of $25,000 may
be provided by amendment while
the bill is on file, pending its second reading. .

During the past two weeks, the
Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Team defeated one team, that of
the Oregon Agricultural College,
and made scores against both the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Rensslaer College,
which are expected to add two
more victories to the club's record.
The Oregon Agricultural College was defeated on March 17.
Although the two scores were really a tie, each team having shot 979,
the match was given to Hopkins
because of several exceedingly high
scores made by individuals on the
team. Consequently, the victory is
due to W. B. Pratt, who shot the
perfect score of 200, and to H. A.
Rowland, who made 199. The
other scores made by the members
of the Hopkins squad were 196,
byj. M. C. Van TIulsteyn 192 by
J. W. Young, and 192 by J. E.
Konze. The highest mark made by
the Oregon Aggies was 196.
During- the week of March 20,
the club held a match with the five
men- representing the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and
made a score of 904, the second to
ighest aggregate score shot by
any team in the National Rifle
League this year. A number of
men who have been shooting steadily, but who have not starred, came
to the front in this match. Pratt,
as usual, shot 200, and Rowland
and Sanner, '18, followed close
with 198 each. The other two tallies were 194 by Wiggins, and 194
by Chisholm. Although the official
results have not yet been announced, there is no doubt in the minds
of the members of the club that
they defeated their opponents. •
Last week the match between the
Hopkins team and that of Rensslaer College took place and here
again it is practically certain that
the local squad was victorious.
This week, on April 4, the club
shoots the last match of its indoor
season with Harvard University.

FIRST SPRING MEET APRIL 15
Track Team Meets Navy on that Date.
Practice Soon to Be Transferred to
Homewood—Medical Men Essential to Success of Team.

If the weather permits, the practice of the track team will be transferred to Homewood this week.
Owing to the nearness of the
Navy meet, which occurs on
April 15, at Annapolis, the workouts from now on will be rather
strenuous, so that the men may be
in a condition .to defeat the Middies. The contest should be close,
as Navy has lost several of its
stars who helped to defeat Hopkins last year, and as Hopkins has
lost only one great point-winner—
Tappan.
- The Black List published after
the recent examinations did not injure the track team to any great extent, as it claimed only Sonneborn,
who, however, had very bright
prospects in .the weight events. To
balance this loss, Ruse, another
freshman who promises to do good
work in .the top-yard dash, having
run this distance in JO.I seconds
last year at Towson High School,
became eligible to represent Hopkins.
The team is depending chiefly
upon medical school students for
its success this year. Schumacher,
especially, is showing up well in the
broad-jump, consistently covering
21 feet.
Another good field man
is Groover, who adds materially to
the strength of the squad in the
220 and relay. Yet, although it is
the medical school candidates upon
whom the team most depends, three
men, due to the pressure of their
work, are not able to give much
time to actual training. This difficulty is somewhat overcome by the
making of special arrangements for'
the transportation of the men from
the medical school to the 'cage.

Y.M.C.A. HOLDS ANNUAL ELECTION
Hall Chosen President— New Plan of
Election Effective—Announcement
Made that Sunday Will Not
Speak at Hopkins.

The annual election of officers of
the Young Men's Christian Association took place last Friday at
noon, with the following results:
President, F. P. Hall, 17; VicePresident, A. K. Chalmers, '18;
Recording Secretary, R. F. Hoffman, .18 ; Corresponding Secretary, H. E. Kirk, Jr., 19; Treasurer, W. L. Taylor, 18.
These men will be called together some time in the near future
by the present assistant general
secretary, and will then appoint
their committee chairmen for next
year. After this, the new officers
will immediately enter upon the
fulfillment of their respective duties.
Not only have most of these officers had a large amount of experience in Young Men's Christian
Association work, but all of them
are also prominent in other Hopkins activities. Included in their
number are the present captains of
both the track and the tennis team,
and the manager of the baseball
team.
The plan of electing the officers
at a general mass-meeting of the
students will probably be used altogether in the future. It is felt
that, by this means, the entire University is made to take more active
interest in the affairs of the Association..
That the coming year will be an
unusually successful one for the
Young Men's Christian Association, is the opinion of the present
officers. They point out that, next
fall, the University will be drawn
closer together because of its location at Homewood, and, in this
manner, the Association will be
able to accomplish its work with
increased effectiveness.
The Association has announced
this week, although with much regret, that it will not be possible
for Mr. Sunday to speak at the
University. There seems to be no
time which would be suitable to the
evangelist which would not conflict
with the regular Hopkins curriculum.

The work on the debate on
versal military training with the
universities of North Carolina and
Virginia is now progressing rapidly. The men upholding the opposite sides of the question had a
meeting last week at which the subject in all its phases was thoroughly discussed. The results of the
consultation proved so beneficial
that is has been decided to hold
many such meetings in the future.
With the time for the debate
rapidly drawing near, both teams
are satisfied with the material that
has been gathered and feel that a
double victory is well within the
realm of possibility.

The Turnbull Lectures.

The crowning event of the lecture season of the University is now
in the course of fruition. Since
their foundation, the Turnbull lectures have been regarded in academic circles as one of the most
important series delivered throughout the country, and the men who
have been selected under this
foundation in the past have been
men who have stood to the fore in
their respective fields, and who
have enjoyed reputations for
scholarship not only in this country,
but also throughout all Europe.
The selection made by the committee this year, measured by these
standards, is particularly happy.
Dr. More is a man who, both
in scholastic and in journalistic endeavor, has achieved heights which
grant to him, without question, the
right to be considered one of the
foremost literary men of the day.
His subject also is one which is of
peculiar interest to Hopkins men,
including as it does the consideration of Sidney Lanier, the poet
whom Hopkins will always proudly
regard as its own. Yet, in itself,
the subject of "The Poets of
America" should be one to awaken
interest in every man who has
dipped, even if only slightly, into
the pages of our national literature.
The enormous attendance which
each of the lectures so far given
has drawn is ample proof of the
keen interest and delight which the
announcement of both lecturer and
subject has evoked throughout the

NINE DOES WELL IN FIRST GAME
Playing for First Time in Open, Allow
Baltimore Orioles to Score Only
9 Runs—Creditable Showing
Bodes Well for Hopkins.

The Hopkins baseball team appeared before the public for the
first time this season when they met
the Baltimore Orioles at Oriole
Park last Saturday afternoon, and
held them to the creditable score of
9 too.
The Hopkins nine has had practically no outdoor work this year,
and previous to the game, had batted against only straight balls. The
practice game with the Orioles was
scheduled only a week ago, and,
all things considered, the fact that
the local nine held the professionals
to a score which would not have
disgraced a member of the International League, despite the fact
that the Orioles have been in training grounds over a month, bodes
well for the outlook of the team.

'VARSITY WINS FIRST GAME
(Continued from page 1)

to return to form is a week of hard
practice.
Of the men who made their first
appearance as 'Varsity players,
Schmidt and Swartz deserve especial mention. The former played a splendid game at cover-point
during the time he was in the game,
and while at times a bit uncertain
in his "going through," showed•
much natural athletic ability.
Swartz was at first very wild in his
attempts at goal, when substituted
in the second half, but toward the
end of the contest settled down and
showed work of considerable promise. Meyer and Wilson also played
well, but not in a noticeable manner. A word should, however, be
said of the work of Arthur Knipp
at in-home. Knipp last played on
the 'Varsity team in 1906, but his
work gave no evidence of the lapse
of years; "once a lacrosse player,
always a lacrosse player."
For the Alumni, La Motte, Mealy.
and Lowndes were the bright
lights: The first two did all their
team's scoring while advisor "Bob"
was a wonder in the mid-field. His
condition was probably the best of
the Alumni, since he had practiced
steadily with the 'Varsity for over
a week. In addition to them the
whole Alumni defense should be
mentioned, especially the work of
Chalmers at goal. Walter Blank
was not on the job for the graduates
for the first time in many years,
and in his stead Chalmers, who is
a 'Varsity sub, was used. Some of
his stops were of a most spectacular nature and he gives promise of
being a most worthy substitute for
Stuart.
As has been the custom, for
years, no admission was charged
for the contest, and an audience of
over 800 friends of the teams were
present in response to the invitations which had been sent out. The
student body, however, was not at
all well represented and had there
been need of cheering it would have
been impossible. The coaches and
the team as a whole look for, and
confidently expect, better support
on next Saturday when Cornell is
to meet in the first intercollegiate
contest.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 3, 1916.

DESCRIBES PROBLEM OF GERMANS DESCRIBE PLATTSBURG CAMPS
Professor Bonn Gives Series of Lectures
on Germany's Present Economic Situation—Says She Was Reluctant to Enter the War.

Messrs. Hoffman and Stuart Tell Why
Hopkins Men Should Attend, Give De- 1
tails of Camps and Show How Expense Can Be Met by All.

Much interest was taken, both
by members of the University and
by outsiders, in the series of lectures delivered in McCoy Hall last
week by Prof. Moritz j. Bonn, of
the University, of Munich, on "Germany's Economic Problem."
In the first of these lectures,
Professor Bonn explained that, in
order that the peculiar genius of
the German people.. might be developed, it was necessary for them to
remain under the German •flag, and
for them to 'speak the. German language.
In his second lecture, he traced
the development of the Germans
from an agricultural to an industrial people. He explained that this
change was brought about so that
work might be found for the ever
increasing; population of. Germany.
He also told how Germany had
adapted itself to these new conditions.
In the final lecture, Dr. Bonn
told of. Germany's international
trade relations. "Germany," he
said, "is in the. very peculiar position of being the only great power
today that has novcolorties of importance." If • England, a'ftth-.. this
war, were .to successfully follow
the example of France, 'Russia and
Japan, he went on, the condition
of Germany's foreign trade would
be very serious, for these countries
charge prohibitive duties on all
goods sent to their colonies from
other nations. Germany has never
wanted to have great colonial possessions like England and France,
he explained, because of her geographical situation.

kt a meeting held at i o'clock
on Monday in McCoy Hall, the
military training camps at Plattsburg, N. Y., were described and
their advantages were discussed by
Messrs. R. • Curzon Hoffman, Jr.,
and Redmond Stuart.
Dean Brush acted as chairman of
the meeting and after a brief speech
introduced' the first speaker, Mr.
Hoffman. Mr. Hoffman" talked on
the history of military camps for
students. He said that they have
been in existence for several years
and have always been well attended,
the number of campers ranging
from 400 to 1,200.
Mr. Stuart, who was the next
speaker, told- of the purpose of the
camps and of the expense involved.
The object of the, camps, he said,
is'to train men' between .tlie:ages. of
18 and 45 in the science of military
drill and maneuvers, and to give
each attendant,as much of the, fundamental education of an .o'ffi'cer
can be imparted in the given.time.
A certain definite routine is Prescribed for all, Mr. Stuart went on,
including infantry training and rifle
practice,. The.. • attendant .,!a,t the
camp are divided into war-strength
companies . of infantry,-' each • of
which is commanded by an officer
of the regular army, whose duties
cover not only those of instruction,
but also those of supervision over
the health and general welfare of
their commands. No examination
is required, but the regular officers
on duty at the camp will make such
reports as to individual qualifications as they may deem proper, to
be filed will; the War Department.
The student camp at Plattsburg,
Which Hopkins men are especially
urged to attend, lasts from July 5.
to•..-kug-ust 8. The expenses at the
camp itself are $22.50, but the total
expenses are nearly $50. The plan
advanced by Mr. Stuart to allow
all to meet this expense is for the
Hopkins students interested in the
camp to form a club and elect a
secretary. Then, if a member could
not. afford to go to the camp this
summer, he could give his name to
the secretary who, in turn, would
notify Mr. Gustavus Ober, secretary of the Maryland National Defense League. Mr. Ober, Mr.
Stuart said, could in all probability
furnish the desired funds. Although no definite organization 'of,
this club has been made, it is probable that such organization will
soon take place.
All who are interested in the
camp can obtain any desired information from Dean Brush or Dr.
Abercrombie.

BILL TO CUT HOPKINS GRANT
INTRODUCED IN LEGISLATURE

A bill has been finally introduced
in the House of Representatives of
the Maryland Legislature by which
the appropriation of the State to
Johns Hopkins University is made
only $50,000, a decrease of $25,000
from the grant of last year.
The bill was introduced on
March 31 by Mr. Bryant, chairman
of the Ways and Means Committee.
Together with the grant to this
University, it carries appropriations to charitable and other institutions supported, wholly or in
part, by the State.
Hope for the full grant of former years to the University has
been by no means abandoned, despite the introduction of the bill.
There is a determined group of
men in the Legislature who are
fighting to the last ditch against the
cut, and there still seems to be an
excellent probability of their efforts
being successful. It is possible that
the additional grant of $25,000 may
be provided by amendment while
the bill is on file, pending its second reading. .

During the past two weeks, the
Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Team defeated one team, that of
the Oregon Agricultural College,
and made scores against both the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Rensslaer College,
which are expected to add two
more victories to the club's record.
The Oregon Agricultural College was defeated on March 17.
Although the two scores were really a tie, each team having shot 979,
the match was given to Hopkins
because of several exceedingly high
scores made by individuals on the
team. Consequently, the victory is
due to W. B. Pratt, who shot the
perfect score of 200, and to H. A.
Rowland, who made 199. The
other scores made by the members
of the Hopkins squad were 196,
byj. M. C. Van TIulsteyn 192 by
J. W. Young, and 192 by J. E.
Konze. The highest mark made by
the Oregon Aggies was 196.
During- the week of March 20,
the club held a match with the five
men- representing the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and
made a score of 904, the second to
ighest aggregate score shot by
any team in the National Rifle
League this year. A number of
men who have been shooting steadily, but who have not starred, came
to the front in this match. Pratt,
as usual, shot 200, and Rowland
and Sanner, '18, followed close
with 198 each. The other two tallies were 194 by Wiggins, and 194
by Chisholm. Although the official
results have not yet been announced, there is no doubt in the minds
of the members of the club that
they defeated their opponents. •
Last week the match between the
Hopkins team and that of Rensslaer College took place and here
again it is practically certain that
the local squad was victorious.
This week, on April 4, the club
shoots the last match of its indoor
season with Harvard University.

FIRST SPRING MEET APRIL 15
Track Team Meets Navy on that Date.
Practice Soon to Be Transferred to
Homewood—Medical Men Essential to Success of Team.

If the weather permits, the practice of the track team will be transferred to Homewood this week.
Owing to the nearness of the
Navy meet, which occurs on
April 15, at Annapolis, the workouts from now on will be rather
strenuous, so that the men may be
in a condition .to defeat the Middies. The contest should be close,
as Navy has lost several of its
stars who helped to defeat Hopkins last year, and as Hopkins has
lost only one great point-winner—
Tappan.
- The Black List published after
the recent examinations did not injure the track team to any great extent, as it claimed only Sonneborn,
who, however, had very bright
prospects in .the weight events. To
balance this loss, Ruse, another
freshman who promises to do good
work in .the top-yard dash, having
run this distance in JO.I seconds
last year at Towson High School,
became eligible to represent Hopkins.
The team is depending chiefly
upon medical school students for
its success this year. Schumacher,
especially, is showing up well in the
broad-jump, consistently covering
21 feet.
Another good field man
is Groover, who adds materially to
the strength of the squad in the
220 and relay. Yet, although it is
the medical school candidates upon
whom the team most depends, three
men, due to the pressure of their
work, are not able to give much
time to actual training. This difficulty is somewhat overcome by the
making of special arrangements for'
the transportation of the men from
the medical school to the 'cage.
